title: Feature Extraction on Breast Cancer Signatures

author: Jonatan Taminau, Computational Modeling Lab, Vrije Universiteit Brussel

segmentation: So my name is Jonathan, I'm from the Free University of Brussels and I'm glad to start this second poster session with my poster titled Feature Extraction and Breast Cancer Signatures.
Actually, the title is a bit misleading because what we actually did is in this study.
Is this sequential application of feature selection and feature extraction on expression data from breast cancer signatures.
So as we saw in the previous presentation before coffee break, breast cancer is a very heterogeneous disease.

And a lot of breast cancer signatures signatures are proposed in literature and they try to predict the survival outcome of patients or they try to predict the cancer aggressiveness and therefore it's so interesting if you have a predictor to say to avoid unnecessary chemotherapy for example so.
But what we noticed was that most of those above those methods to find those signatures are quite simple in nature as at least from a machine learning.
Perspective, but they most of the time do is some cherry picking of genes to obtain a subset of genes that gives you then, in your particular study, the highest predicted outcome.
So what we would like to try to do is also try to use some more complex methods.
The feature extraction methods because they try to lower the dimension in which we are working by transforming the data obtained by those gene expression.
Matrices so this is our overview of our methodology.
We start with the macro data.
In our case we used to transmit data set because it was used before as a benchmark data set too.
To compare the different breast cancer signatures as a feature selection stuff, we just simply select the signatures that exist.
For example, the gene 70, the gene 76 to TGI and then on top we used also feature extraction.
We use several techniques like principle component analysis, the most popular but also the ECN matrix factorization MF.

And the idea is that we lowered the dimension of the number of genes to a dimension of let's say 1015, which are then not the jeans itself as features, but more some linear combinations that features.
So we try to compress that space.
Down to validate, we applied some clustering.
A simple K means clustering with K = 2 and then the idea is to find some natural clustering.
For example the very aggressive cancers and not so aggressive cancers.
And then we used several survival analysis techniques to validate those.
For example, we applied.
We found some hazard ratios and we present also some Kaplan Meier analysis.
All those details of those validation or in the.
Papers and can also be seen in the in the poster.
On the idea of this of this study was first to validate if you use feature extraction, can you open improvement?

And there's also that there is indeed an improvement and the next step you would like to do is further interpret those results, because now we don't have a simple list of genes, but we have some some linear combination of genes that we want to try to see.
How do we interpret it can be mapped to part ways and so further on.
So for all details you can refer to the poster which is that baby bond posters 'cause it's not indicated here.
Thank you very much.
